item.title: Powerboy's C++ Program Collection LOG(WILL KEEP UPDATING) [5 programs so far]
item.dc:creator: @eFox eFox
item.description:
@eFox wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:23, topic:521021”]I have adapted The Enforcer’s superior C++ code to be even more useful, it now detects the type of any integer and returns it as a string.

std::string getIntegerType(long unknown) { std::string type = "NaN"; for (char c = std::numeric_limits<char>::min(); c <= std::numeric_limits<char>::max(); c++) { if (unknown == c) { type = "char"; } } for (short s = std::numeric_limits<short>::min(); s <= std::numeric_limits<short>::max(); s++) { if (unknown == s) { type = "short"; } } for (int i = std::numeric_limits<int>::min(); i <= std::numeric_limits<int>::max(); i++) { if (unknown == i) { type = "int"; } } for (long l = std::numeric_limits<long>::min(); l <= std::numeric_limits<long>::max(); l++) { if (unknown == l) { type = "long"; } } return type; }[/quote]
original

item.title: Powerboy's C++ Program Collection LOG(WILL KEEP UPDATING) [5 programs so far]
item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

I have adapted The Enforcer’s superior C++ code to be even more useful, it now detects the type of any integer and returns it as a string.

std::string getIntegerType(long unknown) { std::string type = "NaN"; for (char c = std::numeric_limits<char>::min(); c <= std::numeric_limits<char>::max(); c++) { if (unknown == c) { type = "char"; } } for (short s = std::numeric_limits<short>::min(); s <= std::numeric_limits<short>::max(); s++) { if (unknown == s) { type = "short"; } } for (int i = std::numeric_limits<int>::min(); i <= std::numeric_limits<int>::max(); i++) { if (unknown == i) { type = "int"; } } for (long l = std::numeric_limits<long>::min(); l <= std::numeric_limits<long>::max(); l++) { if (unknown == l) { type = "long"; } } return type; }

Read full topic

item.title: Powerboy's C++ Program Collection LOG(WILL KEEP UPDATING) [5 programs so far]
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

[quote=“Rodgerwilco, post:21, topic:521021”][quote author=Uncalled link=topic=639529.msg4311441#msg4311441 date=1370802629]
I’m surprised The Enforcer hasn’t came about this thread.
[/quote]

I embarrassed myself in front of him so he left these forums. He is superior.[/quote]

Maybe, but I’m back.

I suggest integrating this superior integer identifying function into your programs.

bool isInteger(int unknown)
{
	for (long long i = INT_MIN; i <= INT_MAX; ++i)
	{
		if (unknown == i)
			return true;
	}

	return false;
}

item.title: Powerboy's C++ Program Collection LOG(WILL KEEP UPDATING) [5 programs so far]
item.dc:creator: @powerboy123 powerboy123
item.description:
@powerboy123 wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:11, topic:521021”]Mastering C++ takes a long, long time. Good luck, and if you are serious about learning the language I suggest you buy a book on it. Judging your code so far I can assume you are using online videos/guides on learning the language so far, in which case stop. These tutorials suck, and you don’t actually learn how to utilize the language.

Here’s a couple of books that I like.
C++ Primer (5th Edition) by Stanley B. Lippman
The C++ Programming Language, 4th Edition by Bjarne Stroustrup (the creator of C++)

Both of these book cover the latest standard of C++, C++11.[/quote]
Thanks for the feedback. And your right, I have been using videos/tuts online.

Read full topic

@imthenull wrote:

Mastering C++ takes a long, long time. Good luck, and if you are serious about learning the language I suggest you buy a book on it. Judging your code so far I can assume you are using online videos/guides on learning the language so far, in which case stop. These tutorials suck, and you don’t actually learn how to utilize the language.

Here’s a couple of books that I like.
C++ Primer (5th Edition) by Stanley B. Lippman
The C++ Programming Language, 4th Edition by Bjarne Stroustrup (the creator of C++)

Both of these book cover the latest standard of C++, C++11.

item.dc:creator: @powerboy123 powerboy123
item.description:
@powerboy123 wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:7, topic:521021”][quote author=powerboy123 link=topic=639529.msg4310702#msg4310702 date=1370701373]
Lol @ all the haters. I bet you guys cant even do this XD
[/quote]
HAHAHAHAHAHAHA

Based on your first three programs, I suggest you start looking at functions, and splitting your program into them appropriately. Additionally, you should look at more control statements/loops such as “do while”, “for loop”, “case statements” etc. Once you’ve got the hang of writing your own functions and the basic control/loop statements, you should start looking at the object orientated part of c++ because at the moment you’re really just producing C code (well except the i/o).[/quote]

Yeah Im looking into classes and functions. I dont see much use for them right now since Im creating simple programs.

Read full topic

item.title: Powerboy's C++ Program Collection LOG(WILL KEEP UPDATING) [5 programs so far]
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

powerboy123:

Lol @ all the haters. I bet you guys cant even do this XD

HAHAHAHAHAHAHA

Based on your first three programs, I suggest you start looking at functions, and splitting your program into them appropriately. Additionally, you should look at more control statements/loops such as “do while”, “for loop”, “case statements” etc. Once you’ve got the hang of writing your own functions and the basic control/loop statements, you should start looking at the object orientated part of c++ because at the moment you’re really just producing C code (well except the i/o).

Read full topic

item.title: Powerboy's C++ Program Collection LOG(WILL KEEP UPDATING) [5 programs so far]
item.dc:creator: @powerboy123 powerboy123
item.description:
@powerboy123 wrote:

5)6/21/2013
Coded a program that was coded in java by another person. This tells what your age is gonna be in future years.

[code]#include

using namespace std;

int main () {
int ageNow;
int year;
int ageResult;
int newAge;
int years;

cout << “Enter your age” << endl;
cin >> ageNow;
cout << “What year is it right now” << endl;
cin >> year;

cout << “Enter the year you want to know your age” << endl;
cin >> ageResult;
newAge=ageResult-year+ageNow;

cout << "You are " << newAge << " in the year " << ageResult << endl;

system(“PAUSE”);
return 0;
}
[/code]

4)6/8/2013
I just learned how to use switch+case for quizzes. Made a simple quiz with a few questions. Try it out here:
https://www.dropbox.com/s/6ziitg9j518obwz/Simplequiz.exe
Here is the code for it:

[code]#include
#include
using namespace std;

int main() {

char response;
char response1;
cout<<“Do you wish to continue(Y/N)”;
cin>>response;
switch(response)
{
case ‘y’: cout << “Good job. Get ready for the test\n”;

 break;

case ‘n’: cout << “You suck. Leave now.\n”;
break;
default: cout<<“invalid choice”;
break;
}
cout << “1.Are lions mammals? Y/N\n”;
cin >> response;
switch (response) {
case ‘y’: cout << “You are a pro! :)\n”;
break;
case ‘n’: cout << “You are really dumb >:(\n”;
break;
default: cout <<“LOL yes or no only\n”;
}
cout << “2. Is 2+2=4? Y/N\n”;
cin >> response;
switch (response) {
case ‘y’: cout << “You are a pro! :)\n”;
break;
case ‘n’: cout << “You are really dumb >:(\n”;
break;
default: cout <<“LOL yes or no only\n”;

}
cout << “3.Apples are blue Y/N\n”;
cin >> response;
switch (response) {
case ‘y’: cout << “You are really dumb >:(\n”;
break;
case ‘n’: cout << “You are a pro! :)\n”;
break;
default: cout <<“LOL yes or no only\n”;

}

system(“PAUSE”);
return 0;
}
[/code]

3)6/8/2013
I built a simple calculator today. If anyone wants to use it, you can download it here: https://www.dropbox.com/s/cs5sowxl7gwezrm/Calculator.exe

The code is:

[code]#include
using namespace std;
double add();

int main() {
cout << “1.add\n” << “2.subtract\n” << “3.multiply\n” << “4.divide\n” << “5.What is PI?\n” << endl;

int x;
int y;
int answer;
int choice;
cin >> choice;
if (choice==1) {
cout << “Enter two numbers to add\n”;
cin >> x;
cin >> y;
answer=(x+y);
cout << "The answer is " << answer <<endl;
}
else if (choice==2) {
cout << “Enter two numbers to subtract\n”;
cin >> x;
cin >> y;
answer=(x-y);

cout << "The answer is " << answer <<endl;
}
else if (choice==3) {
cout << “Enter two numbers to multiply\n”;
cin >> x;
cin >> y;
answer=(x*y);

cout << "The answer is " << answer <<endl;
}
else if (choice==4) {
cout << “Enter two numbers to divide\n”;
cin >> x;
cin >> y;
answer=(x/y);

cout << "The answer is " << answer <<endl;
}
else if (choice==5) {
cout << “PI IS 3.14159265359”;

}

system(“PAUSE”);
return 0;
}

[/code]

2)6/7/2013
This code is a little more complex than the last code.
DOWNLOAD LINK:
https://www.dropbox.com/s/cei25ctuqc5uzfo/Number%202%20Code.exe

[code]#include

using namespace std;

int main() {
int a;

cout << “1.Eat a dog\n” << “2.Eat a cat\n” << “3.LOL WTF\n” << “4.NA DO NOTHING\n”;
cin >> a;
if (a==1) {
cout << “WOOF WOOF ATE THE DOG\n”; }
else if (a==2) {
cout << “MEEOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOW\n”; }
else if (a==3) {
cout << “WTFFFFFFFFF IS THISSSSSSSS\n”; }
else if (a==4) {
cout << “IT DID SOMETHING\n”;
while (a==4) {
cout << “YES”;
} }

system(“PAUSE”);
return 0;
}
][/code]

1)6/7/2013
Had some extra time so I created a program. Im still learning. :D. Feel free to run this or use it however you please.

[code]#include
#include
using namespace std;

int main() {
string username;
int year;
cout << “What is your Moparscape forum username\n”;
cin >> username;
cout << “What year did you register?\n”;
cin >> year;
if (year>=2010) {
cout << “You are a NOOOOOOB\n”; }
else if (year<=2009) {
cout << “You sir are part of a proud MOPAR Community :)\n”; }

system(“PAUSE”);
return 0;
}[/code]
